title: Prognostic Scores: R-ISS (Revised International Staging System) – Multiple Myeloma
summary: Comprehensive guide to the Revised International Staging System (R-ISS) for multiple myeloma, including its components, clinical applications, and future directions.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Topic 5: R-ISS (Revised International Staging System) – Multiple Myeloma

Multiple myeloma (MM) is a heterogeneous plasma cell malignancy that affects the bone marrow and produces monoclonal immunoglobulins (M-protein). It accounts for ~10% of hematologic cancers and has a relapsing-remitting course, with significant interpatient variability in progression and survival.

The Revised International Staging System (R-ISS), introduced by the International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) in 2015, incorporates key tumor burden and biologic risk markers to stratify patients more accurately than its predecessors.

content.text: R-ISS reflects modern treatment realities, including the use of proteasome inhibitors, immunomodulatory drugs, and monoclonal antibodies.
A tumor mass–based system. Criteria included:

items: Hemoglobin
Serum calcium
X-ray findings (osteolytic lesions)
Urine M-protein
Inadequate in the modern imaging and molecular era.
Does not reflect clonal heterogeneity or response predictors.
β₂-microglobulin (β₂M): Reflects tumor burden and renal clearance.
Serum albumin: Reflects nutritional status and systemic inflammation.

content.text: Drawback: Fails to capture biologic aggressiveness or cytogenetic risk.
R-ISS builds upon ISS by incorporating cytogenetic abnormalities and LDH, allowing a more nuanced risk assessment.

R-ISS does not determine transplant eligibility, which is based on:
- Age
- Comorbidity (e.g., cardiac, renal)
- Performance status

However, high R-ISS stage (especially III) may influence:
- Earlier use of ASCT.
- Consideration of tandem ASCT.
- More intensive maintenance post-transplant.

content.text: To overcome R-ISS limitations, next-generation tools are under development:

items: R2-ISS: A refined model incorporating more risk levels, especially for R-ISS II.

MRD-guided frameworks:
- Treatment de-escalation in MRD-negative patients.
- Intensification in MRD-positive or high-risk relapse cases.

Genomic models:
- Whole-exome or RNA-seq–based prediction of progression.
- Use of AI and machine learning for multi-modal integration.

content.text: The Revised International Staging System (R-ISS) is the current gold standard for staging newly diagnosed multiple myeloma. By combining:

items: Tumor burden (β₂M, albumin),
Disease biology (cytogenetics),
Proliferative activity (LDH),

content.text: ...it enables more precise risk stratification than ISS alone.
Though static and limited in mid-risk cases, R-ISS remains essential for:

items: Baseline prognosis
Treatment planning
Trial enrollment

content.text: Ongoing developments such as R2-ISS, MRD-driven models, and genomic predictors will likely augment or replace R-ISS in the coming years as MM care becomes more personalized.

items: Perform R-ISS staging for all newly diagnosed MM patients
Include FISH for high-risk cytogenetics in initial workup
Use R-ISS to guide discussions about prognosis and treatment intensity
Consider additional risk stratification with MRD assessment post-treatment
Stay updated on emerging models like R2-ISS for mid-risk patients
